messageBody:
Marko,

I recommend breaking the problem into three steps:

1) Selenium tests that work from command-line junit. You should be able to
find many resources on this.
2) Getting those tests to run from maven. I have little to contribute here,
but others on-list or on Google might.
3) Optimizing the acceptance-test-writing process. In the absence of strong
AI, the process of translating business requirements into acceptance tests
is always going to be an engineering task, which needs skill and time in
your process. I would suggest owning it as an engineering team, with gentle
hand-off of small parts as it becomes _obvious_ people closer to product
ownership can do them.

Hope that helps,

David

On Tue, Feb 24, 2009 at 7:45 AM, majkic@... <majkic@...> wrote:

> WOW. I'm really impressed with seriousness you approached to
> acceptance testing.
>
> On the other hand it seems that much work was involved to make this
> acceptance framework work fine.
>
> I would like to make our Selenium tests work automatically from CI
> server (linux server without X), as any JUnit test would work. This
> way our Product Owner (yes, we're Scrumming) could write all necessary
> acceptance tests instead of descriptive acceptance criteria.
>
> CI is executing "mvn clean install" periodically and it would be great
> if we could automate this process.
>
> Any ideas?
>
> Thanks,
> Marko
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Fredrik Wendt <fredrik@...> wrote:
> >
> > On fre, 2009-02-20 at 13:25 +0000, majkic@... wrote:
> > > Hi guys,
> > > I need to create automated acceptance tests. Selenium seems to be
> > > nice, since it allows someone without much (or none at all)
> > > programming experience, as our Product Owner to create those tests
> > > with Firefox Selenium IDE plug-in.
> > >
> > > But time has come to integrate those tests to other JUnit tests, so
> > > these can be run on CI server.
> >
> > Disclaimer: No JUnit, no Selenium-RC used in the solution below.
> >
> > What we did is to put all Selenium tests (HTML source) in a separate
> > web-app, bundled with Selenium Core and an index.jsp that starts the
> > test automatically when called by a browser. (We also mangled Selenium
> > Core to let a USERNAME and PASSWORD Selenium variables be set and
> > present in all tests - mangled means five lines of javascript code.)
> >
> >
> > To have it run in a CI environment ... I wrote two applications:
> >
> > a) a simple app called "test agent" that can take two commands over
> > XML-RPC:
> > a1) start a browser pointing it at a certain URL (pointing to the
> > index.jsp file mentioned above, also telling the browser where the
> > selenium result should be posted)
> > a2) stop a browser
> >
> > b) A web-app called "test conductor" that
> > b1) keeps track of test agents
> > b2) aggregate results returned from browsers
> > b3) register test new test runs and launch them when test agents become
> > idle
> >
> > This works well and having the test files in HTML (with human readable
> > ID values on all elements the test interacts with) makes it useful for
> > manual testing as well. Since the web-app with test can be deployed on a
> > developers machine, a developer can also ask the test conductor to run a
> > test off the developer's machine (and start debugging server side).
> >
> > There's no JUnit integration. We just added a simple script on our CI
> > environment (Hudson) that after each successful build of the full
> > software stack does:
> > i) download the build artifacts, deploy them to a test server
> > ii) register a new test run with web-app b mentioned above
> > iii) waits for b to return a fail/success
> > iv) undeploys the artifacts from step i
> >
> >
> > This was all setup one year ago - the client I worked for wasn't sure
> > what Selenium could do or if they wanted to invest time using it. Having
> > the test written/saved in human readable HTML was a good selling point -
> > if they decided to not go with Selenium then the tests could still be
> > used "as is".
> >
> > Since then:
> > Selenium 1.0 still hasn't been released.
> > There's still no Selenium Driver that can use HTML files as source.
> > 3000+ runs completed.
> > We run test agents for FF2, FF3, IE7, Safari on Mac.
> >
> > Parts of the test agent and test conductor is BSD-licensed, some parts
> > where developed for the client (and I think they'll be happy to share
> > under BSD-ish license).
> >
> > / Fredrik
